top_comment.text:
These two seem like the average American hipster, trying so hard to be 
“cultured” that it comes off as pretentious. Don’t get me wrong, it’s great 
to see people being accepting of other cultures, beliefs, and ways of life; 
however, the way in which they present information about Korea as being a 
matter of fact makes it seem like two white people who went abroad, studied 
the culture they deem so different from their own, and returned to report 
back to other white people about what these “exotic” people do. They act 
like Jane Goodall returning to “civilization” to report about how surprised 
they are that people who aren’t white aren’t still living in caves and 
beating each other over the head with clubs. While that is clearly an 
exaggeration, it holds the same appearance as what I have seen in this 
video. The information about Korean culture itself may be totally fine, but 
the way that they are reporting it in these videos makes it seem like 
scientific observations about a strange new species. I am not linking 
Korean culture to that of wild animals, I’m just saying that white 
Americans often seem to do that to other cultures, and these two are no 
exception. There are ways to share one’s interest and excitement about a 
culture different from the one in which they grew up, but this channel 
altogether looks like a high school social studies report with different 
paragraphs (videos) about different aspects that are clearly defined and 
reported as science. No culture can be defined as such. No culture fits 
into black and white categories like this. Noticing differences in culture 
is fine, as there is no denying that there are indeed differences in 
culture all over the world, but exoticizing other cultures as being so 
different from your own is setting a group of people apart based on 
criteria that you are observing, making your own culture seem like the 
“normal” culture and the other culture seem like the “other.” While the two 
people who made this channel may have had good intentions, they try so hard 
to seem unprejudiced that it makes them seem even more prejudiced than they 
probably are.﻿
top_comment.author: LaBelleAraignee

comments.text:
+LaBelleAraignee The way you keep throwing around "white people this" and 
"white people that" is coming off high and mighty and actually pretty 
racist. It's not in any way helping you out. It's as if all and only "white 
people" are like what you're saying. You can say they come off as "snooty",

comments.text:
+James
Feminism works towards equality, and is a portion of Egalitarianism. I 
think that you have been watching too much Fox News, and have this awful 
idea in your head that feminism somehow isn't about equality. Feminism 
deals with problems about gender, specifically dealing with issues that 
women run into. That doesn't make it sexist, no more so than black rights 
groups are somehow racist for trying to tackle issues that specifically 
affect black communities. Feminism is just apart of the equality pie, and 
it doesn't deal with men vs. women no matter how offended MRA groups try to 
get. 1st and 2nd wave feminism deals specifically with women's issues that 
cannot be properly addressed by generalized groups because they are not 
issues that other groups have to deal with on a regular bases. Like how I 
wouldn't really understand the difficulties of discrimination against black 
people, general groups can't really tackle reproductive rights, women being 
denied access to proper health care, or birth control "unless they're 
married".

Modern Feminism specifically deals with the demonetization of traits that 
are deemed arbitrarily feminine in society, and how that attitude affects 
both men and women negatively. Like how a perfectly natural desire for a 
man to be a good father and take care of his kids is seen as "feminine" 
because somehow "parenting" has fallen into the realm of the "feminine". 
Just really think about that for a moment, because it's mentioned in this 
video. How is a father taking care of his children somehow not seen as a 
"male" role? These are purely social constructs that never existed in 
nature.

Modern feminism deals with issues where men get beaten to death in the 
streets for wearing pink, because it's feminine, and seen as lesser, and 
unacceptable for a man to wear (despite the fact that pink used to be seen 
as the male colour, and blue was the female one). It has to do with the 
fact that our society has put out two boxes, labeled one male, one female 
and started throwing random traits that have nothing to do with gender into 
each one, labeled "male traits" as good, "female traits" as inferior and 
punish anyone who does not comply with that. Whether it's a female 
electrician (because fine motor skills, and wire placement is 
evolutionarily manly), or a male baker (which used to be a completely male 
dominated trait, but hey, man in the kitchen making something other than 
bacon!?). Modern feminism deals with how arbitrary gender roles prescribed 
to social dynamics do nothing but hinder our society, male or female.

In this video they're talking about the same issue that Japan is facing. 
The idea that a guy is expected to be the sole bread winner, and never be 
able to be the father his kids need. The idea that a woman has to stay in 
the house and stop working to raise a family. These are the main issues as 
to why the Japanese fertility rates are falling. With the population size, 
things are expensive, and guys just don't want to work themselves to death 
to pay for a family they'll never see anyways. Women don't want to work 
themselves through school, get a job, then drop everything to look after 
the kids of a man she'll never see. Else, she can keep her job, and 
basically end up working two full time jobs, her normal one, and then full 
time as a domestic house keeper for a partner that's unwilling to share the 
work and responsibilities of their house hold. So people just aren't 
getting married, all in all, they're not even having sex! Japan has started 
having all female, and all male apartment buildings due to this insanity.

Do you know what would fix that? Doing away with those ridiculous gender 
roles. Doing away with the male and female trait boxes, and stop saying 
that anything "male" is "good", and anything "female" is "bad" even if both 
groups share those traits. Like both men and women being able to be strong, 
smart, confident, weak, shy, naive, ect. These systems make it so that guys 
don't feel like they can ask for help because "MAN UP" will be his answer, 
and his wife will just generally be assumed to be incompetent out of the 
gate because she's a woman. The cost of living is too high in our society, 
in theirs, and globally as a general rule. It just makes sense that both 
PARTNERS share the economic and domestic burdens, and have a sense of 
shared responsibility in the house.

Unless they start adopting feminist ideology (not the femi-nazi strawman 
arguments that Fox News likes to go on about) they're going to end up like 
Japan. I don't know about you, but I think it's unfair to expect my 
boyfriend to support me. I'm an adult, and I'm more than capable of getting 
a job, and not burdening him with all that responsibility. He feels the 
same with the domestics, and we're pretty darn happy about it. But they 
have an obsession with infantizing women in the working environment, and 
men in the home fast, so we'll see how that goes. I'm all for things being 
as 50/50 as they can be, and treating people like people.

awful garbage.  I see so many people calling each other "idiot" and worse 
names on the internet and people are so uncivil.  I really hope that 
society improves but I am trying to keep my optimism realistic.  As you 
know James, emails and short comments can cause misunderstanding because 
the intention does not often come through.  My intention was not to 
patronize you or comment on your personal relationships.  I know nothing 
about you.  It seems that we are wise enough to agree that we should not 
assume things about people nor should we put people into camps.  As a 
friendly suggestion, try not to put too much credence on what is said on 
the internet by internet trolls.  The people who spew their garbage out on 
the internet do not even have the guts to say these things in person.  It 
is only through treating everyone with respect and not making assumptions 
that we can try to change people's mis-impressions and behavior.  Peace and

comments.text:
Yes, I am a woman so I don't have personal experience with being "hated 
upon" as some of these men describe.  But, I am not automatically trying to 
defend my sex. I just don't see the logic in anyone "hating" upon any 
gender (be it man, woman, transsexual, or whatever).  We are all people 
with feelings, etc. and we should all be treated as people.  I think when 
people try to carve out distinctions like gender, etc. and put people into 
camps or classifications, it automatically creates conflict and 
misunderstanding.  I know that it will not necessarily change someone, but 
if someone is bitter towards you, try to "kill them with kindness."  It 
likely won't change them, but you never know.  It sometimes works for me 
and people who have a mis-impression suddenly change because there are all 
types - men who hate women (misogynists) and much worse, there are women 
who hate on other women (those are particularly vicious).  So, James, I am 
really sorry that you feel that some women in your life have disrespected 
you.  As I said, everyone should have their feelings and dignity respected 
as a human being.  But, what I am trying to say is don't assume that people 
hate you and put them into camps or classifications. It's much better when 
everyone remembers not do that and tries to change their attitude by 
showing that respect and kindness can come from a man or a woman. Good luck 
James we will have a better world if we don't put people in camps and we 
each strive to get people with mis-impressions to change.  Sometimes, the 
best way to get others to change is for us to project respect and kindness. 
 We all are a member of the same race -- the human race.

recognize them as issues, because they're not personality based). I agree

shitty to be depressed or cry or feel angry because of your issues that are 
so difficult to fix, as well as of course personal RL stuff that can 
happen. Both of us were ... well, fairly content being on our own. When we 
met, we were not looking for anyone and hadn't been for a while. Not to say

relatively ok with your life and not expect your partner to fix it. A 
partner is like really awesome food. You need to be ok surviving on the 
basics, but once you have the really awesome food, you don't want to let it 
go. Kinda hard to explain, so I hope that made sense.Give and take, you 
both need to bring something to the relationship. And communication, that's

and talk it through. And they should show the same courtesy.My parents 
(I've actually disowned both of them) were the opposite of a good

I live in one of the poorest counties in West Virginia, in the U.S. When it 
came to the part where you mentioned that it was okay if women worked, so 
long as they took care of the kids and cooked and kept house, I thought to 
myself: "Oh my gosh! Korea is like home!" Seriously: Around here, women are 
expected to first be keepers at home and *then* career women. If women go 
to college in West Virginia, that's a side-project: The lives of their 
children and husbands come first. It's ingrained into the minds of the 
young women that they can either be mothers or career women, not both. As a 
result of this, not many women pursue higher education.

Unlike in Korea, I think, most women here tend to get married a little on 
the young side: One of my best friends from high school was married at 
sixteen; another is getting married this year (at eighteen); a cousin of 
mine was married to a man over ten years older than herself at only 
sixteen. At only seventeen, I feel like an old maid, and my grandma already 
goes on about every man I date (or even my best friend!) as if she expects 
me to marry any one of them any time now.

Yet despite getting married young, many women end up getting divorced later 
in life, and without an education or means of supporting themselves or 
their children, most of them are impoverished for life. Personally I think 
it's miserable. 

Anyway, er, I dunno if that's at all similar to South Korean culture 
(having never been to South Korea), but that one sentence you guys said 
completely spawned a bunch of thoughts in my head, and I kind of got a 
little carried away talking. Y'know how it is, lol. I love you guys' 
videos, by the way. I think I've watched nearly all of them in two days. 
O.o﻿
top_comment.author: Anna Faith

comments.text:
+girlwbigbrowneyes I don't really know what to say but for that I 
appreciate you taking the time to explain this to me so well; I enjoyed it 
very much, and it was very informative. :) 

I'm glad to hear that gender equality in Korea is beginning to become more 
commonplace. I'm actually contemplating going overseas to teach English 
after university (specifically in Korea), so that's something very 
comforting to hear.

As for your surprise at my comparison: Here, it goes far beyond the women's 
education and choice to pursue a career. In West Virginia, it also  which 
says that women are to be "keepers at home," and which many of my 
generation continue to take literally.

As for my personal experiences with the male thoughts on women within West 
Virginia: I've dated three boys which were either my age or a year younger 
than myself. Only one of the three of them viewed me as an equal. The other 
two mentioned marriage less than a month after I'd begun to date them, and 
largely ignored me when other males were around - as if my opinions were 
less noteworthy than their own. On that same note, at holiday dinners I've 
noticed that the men here will eat in one part of the house and the women 
will eat in another. The father of my third boyfriend refused to allow his 
daughter to cut her hair, as long hair was "a mark of being a woman". It 
wasn't uncommon for him to say that certain negative behaviors were "just 
like a woman," or to make blonde jokes, or to overrule his wife in any 
decision.   

It's only with the revelation of the Internet that some have managed to 
break free of the mentality that women are mentally and spiritually less 
than men. Still, my ambition of traveling the world - not only to Korea - 
and eventually working my way into politics has caused some amount of alarm 
among the members of my family. My grandmother has expressed the view that 
women are incapable of leading nations or holding government positions, as 
have several of my former schoolteachers. Unfortunately, this and the other 
aforementioned views on women are shared sentiments among many people in 
West Virginia, and unlike in Korea, I believe the situation of the women 
here to be improving at a very slow pace.
comments.author: Anna Faith

comments.text:
Wow. Never would I have imagined that somebody from WV would compare her 
situation to Korea! This is really new to me and I had to write a reply to 
you comment.
As for your question, yes and no. WV and Korea are similar in a way that 
(a) the moms are being the ‘supermoms’ who keep themselves busy doing both 
their work and house chores, and (b) this is due to the traditional and 
conservative view on gender roles, that the house chores are more 
appropriate for women. However, there are clearly differences between them; 
(a) women get equal amount/level of education as men in Korea and (b) the 
family does not come first for all women; their career is important to them 
as much as it is to men, that is, both men and women value their career.
Now that I put it this way, it may be a bit confusing to you, but if you 
understand that Korea has quite a low birth rate, and that the children are 
very precious to the parents, its situation might be a little bit more 
comprehensible. In the past, the Korean government worried about the 
rapidly increasing population and therefore launched a campaign to reduce 
the birth rate. The campaign lasted during the 70’s and 80’s, and it 
actually took effect. The couples started having only one or two children, 
and since there were less children to look after, they started to invest 
more in their education, whether it was a girl or a boy. Before then, when 
there were a lot of children in a family, parents did favor boys because 
Korea, just like a lot of countries over the world, had been a 
male-dominant society for a long time. However, when they started having 
only one or two children, girls were just as dear to them as the boys; the 
parents did not discriminate between them anymore, but gave both of them 
equal love and support. Since then, the girls proved to be just as 
successful as – and oftentimes excelling – the boys at school, and 
therefore could get decent jobs and better careers.
Nowadays, about 80% of Korean people go to universities each year – if you 
include 2-year colleges then it would be over 90% – and last year, 74.3% of 
the girls went to the university while 68.6% of the boys went to the 
university. This would tell you that girls receive no less education than 
boys and that they do pursue a life as a career woman. They don’t go to 
universities to meet nice guys and settle down; they have their own dreams 
and ambitions, and they are not willing to sacrifice them for their future 
husbands and children. The thing is, people’s perception cannot catch up 
with the changing social behaviors, so there are still a lot of people who 
think that it is woman’s job to look after the family and children. Because 
of that, a lot of women turn into ‘supermoms’; it’s hard to fight back the 
social pressure on them, but they still can’t give up their dream job.
However, even though the perception is slow to change, it does change 
overtime. Personally, I think it had changed a lot these days, because when 
I talk about this gender issue with my friends, every single one of them 
has told me that parenting and house chores should be done equally, and it 
would be unfair if either wife or husband has to take on more 
responsibilities than the other. I am pretty sure this is what is on the 
minds of the young people in general. I am 23 year-old girl who is about to 
graduate from one of the SKY universities mentioned in the clip, and trust 
me, the guys in my university are not willing to become breadwinners for 
their ideal hot girls; they, too, believe in gender equality, discuss 
feminism with me, and know that they should respect the careers of their 
loved ones just as they want their careers to be respected. I love Simon 
and Martina and I am often surprised at their precise descriptions of the 
Korean society, but sometimes they can be a little inaccurate because there 
are some deeper things that are just too hard for the foreigners to 
discover. And I’m sorry, but I find this one particular clip quite 
misleading.

top_comment.text:
I don't know about this one... I mean, it is true that pretty people are 
more coveted, but there is a lot of pressure for girls to study hard and to 
get into those SKY universities as well...  Right now, as a Korean student, 
I can safely say that everything takes a backseat to a great education, no 
matter your gender. (and it sucks.)﻿
top_comment.author: Jan Kim

comments.text:
+JaneStone87 I know, and I'm trying to be grateful. It's just hard to be 
happy when people judge you based on your test score. It's like the person 
with the higher test score is worth more as a person, and people get 
special treatment accordingly. You're right though, it is getting better. 
Slowly, but high schools are looking at extra curricular activities and 
permanent records. Of course, the unofficial mindset of the parents and the 
students themselves haven't changed as much, but we're getting there...
comments.author: Jan Kim

comments.text:
+808naty
I believe things will get better as time goes on.
comments.author: JaneStone

comments.text:
+bassoonism
I understand what you mean. I know about the high suicide rates. They do 
need to ease up in Asia in this regard. That's why Ivy leagues in the US 
don't focus solely on grades, but they want students who're involved in 
other extra curricular activities that they're passionate about, namely 
ones that have to do with interacting with other people. That way the 
student is more well rounded and has more developed interpersonal skills 
and is happier in general.
comments.author: JaneStone

comments.text: +JaneStone87 Believe me that is one boring, sad life.
comments.author: 808naty

comments.text:
+JaneStone87 I think what she means is that there is so much pressure to do 
well that ABSOLUTELY NOTHING else matters besides grades and tests. Your 
whole life is just studying. A Korean friend told me that this was one of 
the reasons that the suicide rate is so high.
comments.author: bassoonism

comments.text:
It doesn't suck. There's a reason why Asian countries are so developed and 
highly respected the world over. Be grateful.
